author: By Deb Amlen
title: Bamboozles
description: Neville Fogarty tries to trick us, but he’s all wet.
content: TUESDAY PUZZLE — Moving from Monday-level solving to Tuesday-level solving might not seem like much to veterans, but it requires a huge leap of faith for new solvers. It’s hard enough to learn everything you need to know in order to speak the language of the clues, and — just when you think you’ve got it down — you lift your eyes from the puzzle only to see the rest of the week ahead of you. That’s daunting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: Coronavirus, Russia, Dominic Cummings: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Malia Wollan
title: How to Dance Alone
description: Dance without anyone else watching, but try filming yourself. You don’t have to post it, just witness your body moving to music.
content: “You need almost no space to dance,” says Marlee Grace, 31, who in 2015 started @personalpractice, an Instagram account where she shares video snippets of herself dancing, almost always solo, and often in small living spaces. Grace has recorded dance videos in a 100-square-foot cabin in Point Reyes Station, Calif., and more recently, from her kitchen in Madrid, N.M. “Let the space inform your moves,” she says. “How do you dance with the shape of the stove? Can you bend and twist with the cupboards?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: 98,000 and Counting
description: And what else you need to know today.
content: Nationwide death patterns tend to be remarkably stable. On a typical summer day in recent years, about 7,500 Americans have died. On a typical winter day, slightly more than 8,000 have.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Gorman
title: Wild Cockatoos Are Just as Smart as Lab-Raised Ones
description: Previous research suggested that spending a lot of time with humans might make animals more innovative. These birds had another idea.
content: When it comes to cognitive testing, the Goffin’s cockatoos at the University of Veterinary Medicine in Vienna are pros.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: Amazon Misses a Shopping Opportunity
description: The best shopping ideas now are coming from big box stores. Where are Amazon’s innovations?
content: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giovanni Russonello
title: On Politics: Biden Ventures Out
description: Biden wears a mask in public, but also puts his foot in his mouth: This is your morning tip sheet.
content: Former Vice President Joe Biden, with his wife, Jill Biden, laid a wreath at Veterans Memorial Park at the Delaware Memorial Bridge in New Castle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Judith Shulevitz
title: J.M. Coetzee’s Jesus Sees the World as Don Quixote Does
description: “The Death of Jesus,” the final novel in a trilogy, is a modern fable that challenges our limited understanding of reality.
content: THE DEATH OF JESUSBy J. M. Coetzee
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elian Peltier
title: Visiting My Grandparents, Separated by Plexiglass
description: With a partition in front of him, Elian Peltier, a New York Times reporter, experienced a strange new reality when he checked in on his relations at a nursing home outside Paris.
content: Elian Peltier, who is based in London, covered the coronavirus pandemic in Spain before returning to his home country, France. We asked him to tell us about a visit to his grandparents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Rosman
title: Is This the Breakout Star of Virtual Fitness?
description: Isaac Calpito is “torching” Real Housewives’s rear ends for charity, and you too can join in the fun.
content: Every morning, Isaac Calpito sets the stage in the East Hampton living room of his friend Stephanie DiTullio. Mr. Calpito, 39, is dressed, often, in sparkling yoga tights and a tank top that show his muscles to good advantage. His main prop is an iPhone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Grose
title: When Couples Fight About Virus Risks
description: Should the kids use a public bathroom? Is bike riding with friends allowed? Here’s how to deal with a new kind of parenting disagreement.
content: Lian Chikako Chang and her husband, Drew Harry, agree on the big picture when it comes to minimizing their 3-year-old’s risk of exposure to the coronavirus. They both work in the tech industry and neither is an essential worker, so they have been following California’s shelter-in-place rules and going outside only for curb-side pick up for groceries once a week or brief bouts of exercise. They take their son to local parks on weekdays, because it is less crowded than on weekends.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: The Front Page
description: What do you think of the Times’s decision to mark the grim milestone of 100,000 deaths this way? How else might we as a nation mark and mourn these lives?
content: The front page of The New York Times usually features a colorful mix of articles, photographs and graphics. On Sunday, May 24, however, there was just a list: a long, solemn list of people whose lives were lost to the coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Cacciola
title: How Kobe Bryant Created His Own Olympic Dream Team
description: Bryant, who is set for posthumous induction into the Basketball Hall of Fame this year, powered the United States to a gold medal in 2008 with his trademark work ethic.
content: Kobe Bryant was 17 when he worked out for the Phoenix Suns before the 1996 N.B.A. draft. Jerry Colangelo, who owned the team at the time, already knew a great deal about Bryant, who had emerged from Lower Merion High School in suburban Philadelphia as the flashiest phenom of his generation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Weed
title: The Latest Trend in Vacation Rentals: Long-Term Stays
description: Like a barbershop newly opened from lockdown, vacation properties are experiencing a surge of bookings. But instead of a week or two on the beach, people are looking for a month or more.
content: Within 24 hours of President Trump’s European travel ban in March, Laura Jones had three inquiries to rent her house in the Catskills for a month. “We had never been able to rent it for more than four days before, and most were for just a weekend,” Ms. Jones said. The house has already had two groups for one month each, and a three-month renter will soon take the place.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steve Lohr
title: Remember the MOOCs? After Near-Death, They’re Booming
description: The pioneering online learning networks offer hard-earned lessons for what works and what doesn’t with online education.
content: Sandeep Gupta, a technology manager in California, sees the economic storm caused by the coronavirus as a time “to try to future-proof your working life.” So he is taking an online course in artificial intelligence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Conger and Davey Alba
title: Twitter Grapples Anew With Its Trump Conundrum
description: The social media company came under fire — again — for not removing Mr. Trump’s posts that contain falsehoods.
content: OAKLAND, Calif. — Twitter said last year that it would hide tweets of world leaders behind a warning label if their messages incited harassment or violence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Zinoman
title: Hannah Gadsby’s ‘Douglas’ Doubles Down on the Comedy of Contradiction
description: The new Netflix special from the star of “Nanette” is intricate and heady, but sometimes the cleverness gets in the way.
content: One of the least famous but most revealing radical arguments of Hannah Gadsby’s breakthrough special, “Nanette,” is that we should only dress babies in the color blue. Sorry pink. Pointing out how blue is associated with coolness as well as the hottest part of the flame, she said with admiration that it’s full of contradictions. So is her comedy.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Inequality in America: Finding Answers
description: Readers take on many aspects of the problem, including income, housing, the role of states and a lack of humanity.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edmund Lee
title: HBO Max Wants to ‘Crush’ Netflix. Is It Too Late?
description: AT&T’s streaming platform goes live on Wednesday. At $15 a month, it’s more expensive than its rivals and comes at a time when household income is dropping.
content: HBO has been an innovator for much of its nearly 50-year run. Now, with the unveiling of HBO Max, it’s playing catch-up.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Concepción de León
title: J.K. Rowling Begins Publishing ‘The Ickabog,’ for Children in Lockdown
description: The Harry Potter author said her new fairy tale would go online in installments, starting Tuesday, and published as a book in November.
content: Readers who long imagined themselves in Harry Potter’s world have a chance to immerse themselves in another fictional universe created by J.K. Rowling. The author said Tuesday that she would release “The Ickabog,” a new story for young readers, for free online.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: John von Sternberg, Seller and Protector of Homes, Dies at 79
description: He was a pillar of the community in Mountain Lakes, N.J., a real estate agent and a 60-year volunteer firefighter. He fell victim to Covid-19.
content: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Zinoman
title: Hannah Gadsby’s ‘Douglas’ Doubles Down on the Comedy of Contradiction
description: The new Netflix special from the star of “Nanette” is intricate and heady, but sometimes the cleverness gets in the way.
content: One of the least famous but most revealing radical arguments of Hannah Gadsby’s breakthrough special, “Nanette,” is that we should only dress babies in the color blue. Sorry pink. Pointing out how blue is associated with coolness as well as the hottest part of the flame, she said with admiration that it’s full of contradictions. So is her comedy.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Inequality in America: Finding Answers
description: Readers take on many aspects of the problem, including income, housing, the role of states and a lack of humanity.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edmund Lee
title: HBO Max Wants to ‘Crush’ Netflix. Is It Too Late?
description: AT&T’s streaming platform goes live on Wednesday. At $15 a month, it’s more expensive than its rivals and comes at a time when household income is dropping.
content: HBO has been an innovator for much of its nearly 50-year run. Now, with the unveiling of HBO Max, it’s playing catch-up.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein
title: N.H.L. Announces Plan to Return Straight Into the Playoffs
description: Commissioner Gary Bettman and the N.H.L. Players’ Association agreed to terms on resuming the season with a 24-team playoff format that would yield a champion in early autumn.
content: More than two and a half months after shutting down because of the coronavirus outbreak, the National Hockey League became the largest North American professional sports league to announce definitive plans for a return.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Audra D. S. Burch and John Eligon
title: Bystander Videos Are Policing the Police by Putting Deaths on Display
description: The initial police account of George Floyd’s death in Minneapolis did not mention that an officer’s knee pinned him to the ground. “Please, I can’t breathe,” he said.
content: The Minneapolis police statement was short and sanitized. An allegation of forgery. A suspect who “appeared to be under the influence,” who “physically resisted officers” and who appeared to be “suffering medical distress.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Canned Cocktails From Oregon
description: Four new drinks from Rogue Ales & Spirits hit the sweet spot, though you may want to add a bit more booze.
content: Most canned cocktails are not for me. But the line of carbonated ones now sold nationally by Rogue Ales & Spirits in Newport, Ore., are an exception. They’re blissfully straightforward mixtures of very few ingredients, plus sparkling water. The spirits are Rogue’s own Bayfront Vodka and Farmhouse Gin. The Ginger Lime Vodka Mule and the Cucumber Lime Gin Fizz are my preferences, with the Grapefruit Vodka Soda a runner-up. The Cranberry Elderflower Vodka Soda was too sweet for me. An extra shot of gin or vodka to ramp up the 7.5 percent alcohol a bit improved them all.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Concepción de León
title: J.K. Rowling Begins Publishing ‘The Ickabog,’ for Children in Lockdown
description: The Harry Potter author said her new fairy tale would go online in installments, starting Tuesday, and published as a book in November.
content: Readers who long imagined themselves in Harry Potter’s world have a chance to immerse themselves in another fictional universe created by J.K. Rowling. The author said Tuesday that she would release “The Ickabog,” a new story for young readers, for free online.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kimiko de Freytas-Tamura, Winnie Hu, Lindsey Rogers Cook and Gabriela Bhaskar
title: ‘It’s the Death Towers’: How the Bronx Became New York’s Virus Hot Spot
description: The borough has the city’s highest rates of virus cases, hospitalizations and deaths. Could more have been done?
content: Working on the front lines of the coronavirus pandemic can be hazardous, but staying home isn’t safe either for the emergency responders, pharmacists, home health aides, grocery clerks and delivery men who fill River Park Towers in the Bronx.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Spencer Bokat-Lindell
title: Will the Coronavirus Kill College Admissions Tests?
description: The SAT and ACT could be on their way out. Is that a good thing?
content: This article is part of the Debatable newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it Tuesdays and Thursdays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Meredith Talusan
title: On Being a Trans Woman, and Giving Up Makeup
description: I have short hair. I don’t wear heels. Because there is no one way to be a trans woman, either.
content: I walked briskly through Harvard’s campus, but slowed down as I reached the grassy courtyard, where a crowd of mostly gay men and a smattering of women milled about under a giant white tent. It was a drizzly May afternoon in 2017, 20 years since I graduated, and I was there to attend the college’s queer alumni reception. Yet suddenly, I felt unprepared to see people who had never met me as a woman. I took a breath, then ambled over to the drinks, where I soon spied an old friend named Sean.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kimiko de Freytas-Tamura, Winnie Hu, Lindsey Rogers Cook and Gabriela Bhaskar
title: ‘It’s the Death Towers’: How the Bronx Became New York’s Virus Hot Spot
description: The borough has the city’s highest rates of virus cases, hospitalizations and deaths. Could more have been done?
content: Working on the front lines of the coronavirus pandemic can be hazardous, but staying home isn’t safe either for the emergency responders, pharmacists, home health aides, grocery clerks and delivery men who fill River Park Towers in the Bronx.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giovanni Russonello
title: Jimmy Cobb, Drummer on Miles Davis’s ‘Kind of Blue,’ Dies at 91
description: The last surviving member of that landmark album’s sextet, he was a master of understatement, propelling his bandmates with a quiet persistence.
content: Jimmy Cobb, a jazz drummer whose propulsive ride cymbal imbued countless classic recordings with a quiet intensity, including Miles Davis’s epochal album “Kind of Blue,” died on Sunday in Harlem. He was 91.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: Two Months Later, the Iditarod Champion May Finally Get a Ride Home
description: Because of the coronavirus pandemic, Thomas Waerner of Norway and his dogs have been stranded in Alaska after finishing the race on March 18.
content: Thomas Waerner was contending for the lead in the Iditarod sled dog race in mid-March. Yet as he focused on the race and his dogs, he couldn’t help pick up the whispers at rest stops: Coronavirus. Covid-19. Flights canceled. Borders closed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: Poll Shows One Hurdle to Reopening Broadway: Fear of Jerks
description: A New York Times/Siena College Research Institute poll found that theatergoers who are hesitant to return worry that the people around them won’t follow the rules.
content: New Yorkers are decidedly reluctant to return to Broadway shows in September, according to a new poll, but they are significantly more willing to go by the end of the year — as long as certain safeguards are in place.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word + Quiz: eschatology
description: This word has appeared in five articles on NYTimes.com in the past year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Cowan, Tim Arango and Thomas Fuller
title: What’s Ahead for California’s Economy?
description: Tuesday: Experts weigh in. Also: State leaders make good on Gov. Gavin Newsom’s promise to set rules for reopening houses of worship.
content: Good morning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shannon Doyne
title: Lesson of the Day: ‘After 17 Years Underground, Cicadas Stage a 2020 Southern Invasion’
description: In this lesson, students learn about the life cycle of the cicada and why the return of this insect is exciting news to some and a nuisance to others.
content: Featured Article: “After 17 Years Underground, Cicadas Stage a 2020 Southern Invasion” by Maria Cramer
source.name: The New York Times

title: Coronavirus in N.Y.C.: Latest Updates
description: On Memorial Day, Governor Cuomo said that state and local governments would pay benefits for workers who died while fighting the pandemic.
content: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marie Arana
title: America Is Obsessed With Cuba. But What Do We Know About Its Citizens?
description: “The Cubans,” by Anthony DePalma, paints a detailed, novelistic portrait of a handful of ordinary Cubans — their hopes, political beliefs and struggles to get by.
content: THE CUBANS Ordinary Lives in Extraordinary TimesBy Anthony DePalma
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mikkael A. Sekeres, M.D
title: Finding, and Curing, Cancers May Be Another Casualty of Coronavirus
description: As the death tolls rise to the coronavirus pandemic, those of us who specialize in oncology are bracing for another wave of victims: People not yet diagnosed with cancer.
content: Our leukemia team just cared for a young woman who had gone to a hospital 50 miles from ours because she wasn’t feeling well. She had delayed seeing a doctor for weeks, fearing that emergency rooms and urgent care clinics were akin to Covid hot zones. She didn’t want to catch the coronavirus if she didn’t already have it.
source.name: The New York Times

title: New & Noteworthy Audiobooks, From Harry Potter to Kevin Hart
description: A selection of recent audiobooks of interest; plus, a peek at what our colleagues around the newsroom are reading.
content: MY VANISHING COUNTRY: A Memoir, by Bakari Sellers, read by the author. (HarperAudio.) The former South Carolina state representative and current CNN political analyst tells the story of his upbringing within the black working class of the rural South.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Klein
title: David Frum Rethinks Conservatism
description: In “Trumpocalypse,” a former prominent neoconservative reflects on what he got wrong, and where we should go from here.
content: TRUMPOCALYPSERestoring American DemocracyBy David Frum
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Story of Two Brothers From Mexico
description: They died within hours of each other. With the pandemic, bringing their bodies home has become an almost impossible task.
content: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rob Hoerburger
title: My Father Leaned on Routine to Create Stability. Now I Do, Too.
description: His routines were essentially acts of faith. And like even my daily iced coffee, so have mine been.
content: Even by suburban standards, my father’s adherence to routine was astonishing. He took the same train out in the morning and the same train back at night, from the one job at the one company where he worked for almost 47 years, in the unchanging uniform of suit, tie and fedora. He had a worn leather breviary stuffed with prayers and Mass cards he’d been collecting for years, and he read through them all at the dining-room table every night during the 11 o’clock news. He drank exactly one Scotch-and-soda a week, Sunday afternoons during the game. We had the same vacation destination every year, often during the same calendar week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Nagourney
title: Campaigning in a Crisis: Obama, McCain and the 2008 Meltdown
description: Barack Obama and John McCain were rocked by a national emergency during the 2008 campaign, and their responses decided the race, aides say. There are lessons for Joseph R. Biden Jr. and President Trump.
content: It was a late Sunday afternoon in September 2008, and senior aides to Barack Obama were gathered at his presidential campaign headquarters in Chicago. Their latest polling showed that Mr. Obama, the Democratic nominee, had lost his lead over his opponent, Senator John McCain, since the Republican convention. They were worried.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: John McEnroe Is Mindy Kaling’s Voice of Teen Angst. Seriously.
description: McEnroe, the former tennis star, narrates Kaling’s new Netflix series about a 15-year-old Indian-American girl with family and boy problems. “I don’t know why it works,” he said.
content: So it’s the 2019 Vanity Fair Oscar party, and John McEnroe is waiting to get his picture taken by the portrait photographer Mark Seliger, because that’s the kind of party favor you get at the Vanity Fair Oscar party.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clint Edwards
title: How Quarantine Has Brought My Family Closer Together
description: With no weekend sports, volunteering or church obligations, our family connections are flourishing.
content: The other day I was looking over what would have been my kids’ weekend sports schedule had we not entered a shutdown. Tristan, 13, would have had a soccer doubleheader, with games at 9:30 a.m. and 3 p.m. last Saturday, each matchup a 30-minute drive away from the other. Aspen, 6, had a game scheduled at a third field at noon. And Norah, 10, was signed up for gymnastics practice in a fourth location 40 minutes away at 11 a.m.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim McKeough
title: A Spalike Bathroom Where You Can Hide From It All
description: With many spas temporarily shut down, you still need a place to relax and recharge. Here’s how to get it.
content: When a barrage of bad news, glitchy videoconferences and cramped quarters propel stress levels to new highs, it helps to have a place to recharge.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacey Fortin and Johnny Diaz
title: After Crowding at Lake of the Ozarks, Missouri Officials Urge Quarantine
description: “It’s irresponsible and dangerous to engage in such high risk behavior just to have some fun over the extended holiday weekend,” said the mayor of St. Louis.
content: After large crowds gathered at the Lake of the Ozarks over the Memorial Day weekend in defiance of Missouri’s social distancing guidelines, officials in two states urged those visitors to quarantine for two weeks, or until they tested negative for the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Frozen Burek, Ready to Heat
description: Balkan Bites, from an Albanian chef, are hearty, flaky pastries filled with meat and cheese.
content: Alida Malushi, a pastry chef who was born in Kosovo to an Albanian family, came to New York in 1991. With her niece, Ariana, she established Balkan Bites, making and selling her family’s burek, the filled pastries that are widely enjoyed throughout the Balkans, in Turkey and parts of the Middle East. Though she is calling them “bites,” they are considerably larger, almost the size of a bagel. Inside the flaky pastry spiral, there is the choice of meat, a tangy cheese mixture, and a combination of spinach and cheese. The pastries are sold frozen and take about 30 minutes in the oven without prior thawing, to emerge savory and burnished.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Questlove Hosts a Virtual Dinner Party
description: This potluck will be broadcast on the Food Network and will raise money for America’s Food Fund.
content: The cookbook “Mixtape Potluck” by Questlove, the musician and activist, was published last fall. Now Questlove is turning it into a one-hour Food Network special and fund-raiser to be broadcast on Thursday, with celebrity participants like Olivia Wilde, George Lopez, Tiffany Haddish and others cooking, eating and drinking at a virtual dinner party. It benefits America’s Food Fund, a charity founded by Leonardo DiCaprio, Laurene Powell Jobs and Apple to donate funds to other nonprofits like No Kid Hungry. A number to text to donate will appear onscreen during the show.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raymond Zhong
title: China’s Virus Apps May Outlast the Outbreak, Stirring Privacy Fears
description: With the disease there mostly under control, officials are looking for new uses for the government software that’s now on many phones.
content: At the height of China’s coronavirus outbreak, officials made quick use of the fancy tracking devices in everybody’s pockets — their smartphones — to identify and isolate people who might be spreading the illness.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Hauser, Derrick Bryson Taylor and Neil Vigdor
title: ‘I Can’t Breathe’: 4 Minneapolis Officers Fired After Black Man Dies in Custody
description: “Being black in America should not be a death sentence,” the city’s mayor said as video of the arrest was widely shared.
content: The F.B.I. and Minnesota law enforcement authorities are investigating the arrest of a black man who died after being handcuffed and pinned to the ground by an officer’s knee, in an episode that was recorded on video by a bystander and that sparked large protests in Minneapolis on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anita Shet
title: Will the Pandemic Lead to Outbreaks of Other Maladies?
description: Vaccinations worldwide have dropped as the fight against the coronavirus continues.
content: An unusual silence fills the waiting area of my fellow pediatrician’s office in suburban Maryland. On a typical day, one would expect to see the animated bustle of children. Nowadays, only two out of 10 scheduled visits might take place. Unused vaccine vials rapidly accumulate as families shelter at home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Gardner
title: I Am Asking New York Not to Forget Us
description: After 9/11, New York left paramedics behind. I fear the same will happen with the coronavirus.
content: On the morning of Sept. 11, 2001, I was working as a paramedic in Lower Manhattan. I responded to the attacks on the World Trade Center. In dust so thick it shrouded the sun, my fellow rescue workers and I picked our way through the rubble, looking for survivors. Very few of us had masks. When I got home and took a shower, the runoff clogged the drain and collected around my ankles like reconstituted cement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John I. Jenkins
title: We’re Reopening Notre Dame. It’s Worth the Risk.
description: Informed by the best medical advice we can find, we believe we can keep our campus environment healthy.
content: SOUTH BEND, Ind. — Dr. Anthony Fauci, director of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, is a distinguished immunologist and an advocate for public health. I have the privilege of sharing with him an education in Catholic schools laden with the study of classical texts, philosophy and theology.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: North Fork Table & Inn Reopens Its Food Truck
description: An East Village location for a meatpacking bar and restaurant, Indian provisions on the Upper East Side, and more restaurant news.
content: The reopening of North Fork Table & Inn, a highly regarded establishment on Long Island, began Memorial Day weekend with its popular food truck, now in its 10th season. Both closed last fall to cycle through a change of ownership. The chef John Fraser and his JF Restaurants now own it. Mr. Fraser, who has spent summers in Montauk, has long wanted to run a restaurant on Long Island, and the North Fork’s farms and fishing are a perfect fit for his approach to cooking. The chef at the food truck is Steven Barrantes, who worked with Mr. Fraser at Dovetail and Nix, in Manhattan. The menu features a lobster roll, tuna tartare with lettuce and pickled cucumbers, a BLT with avocado (a BLAT), a “smashburger” with a meatless burger as an option, salads and fried chicken. Starting Thursday, the truck is open for takeout five days a week (closed Mondays and Tuesdays), and on July 4 the truck will be open daily. The restaurant is expected to reopen sometime this summer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Lee Myers and Elaine Yu
title: China’s Military Vows to Defend the Country’s Interests in Hong Kong
description: The commander of the People’s Liberation Army garrison in Hong Kong and the city’s leader defended Beijing’s push for new national security laws governing the territory.
content: The commander of China’s military garrison in Hong Kong said in an interview posted Tuesday that forces stationed there would “resolutely” protect the country’s national security interests, a pointed reminder of Beijing’s ultimate power to enforce its rule over the semiautonomous territory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Declan Walsh and Eric Schmitt
title: U.S. Accuses Russia of Sending Warplanes to Libya
description: The unusually sharp assertion by a senior American commander underscored the Pentagon’s concern about Moscow’s growing influence in the country’s sprawling war.
content: CAIRO — The U.S. military accused Russia of covertly deploying at least 14 fighter jets to Libya last week to support Russian mercenaries fighting alongside a beleaguered commander in his campaign to oust the government from Tripoli, the capital.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacey Fortin and Johnny Diaz
title: After Crowding at Lake of the Ozarks, Missouri Officials Urge Quarantine
description: “It’s irresponsible and dangerous to engage in such high risk behavior just to have some fun over the extended holiday weekend,” said the mayor of St. Louis.
content: After large crowds gathered at the Lake of the Ozarks over the Memorial Day weekend in defiance of Missouri’s social distancing guidelines, officials in two states urged those visitors to quarantine for two weeks, or until they tested negative for the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Corum
title: SpaceX Prepares to Launch Two NASA Astronauts
description: The Crew Dragon launch is scheduled for 4:33 p.m. on Wednesday.
content: The Crew Dragon launch is scheduled for 4:33 p.m. on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rob Hoerburger
title: My Father Leaned on Routine to Create Stability. Now I Do, Too.
description: His routines were essentially acts of faith. And like even my daily iced coffee, so have mine been.
content: Even by suburban standards, my father’s adherence to routine was astonishing. He took the same train out in the morning and the same train back at night, from the one job at the one company where he worked for almost 47 years, in the unchanging uniform of suit, tie and fedora. He had a worn leather breviary stuffed with prayers and Mass cards he’d been collecting for years, and he read through them all at the dining-room table every night during the 11 o’clock news. He drank exactly one Scotch-and-soda a week, Sunday afternoons during the game. We had the same vacation destination every year, often during the same calendar week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clint Edwards
title: How Quarantine Has Brought My Family Closer Together
description: With no weekend sports, volunteering or church obligations, our family connections are flourishing.
content: The other day I was looking over what would have been my kids’ weekend sports schedule had we not entered a shutdown. Tristan, 13, would have had a soccer doubleheader, with games at 9:30 a.m. and 3 p.m. last Saturday, each matchup a 30-minute drive away from the other. Aspen, 6, had a game scheduled at a third field at noon. And Norah, 10, was signed up for gymnastics practice in a fourth location 40 minutes away at 11 a.m.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim McKeough
title: A Spalike Bathroom Where You Can Hide From It All
description: With many spas temporarily shut down, you still need a place to relax and recharge. Here’s how to get it.
content: When a barrage of bad news, glitchy videoconferences and cramped quarters propel stress levels to new highs, it helps to have a place to recharge.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti
title: Will Twitter Draw a Line for Trump?
description: Kara Swisher says President Trump is an expert at gaming Twitter, but the company can still step in.
content: Hi. Welcome to On Politics, your guide to the day in national politics. I’m Nick Corasaniti, your host on Tuesdays for our coverage of all things media and messaging.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Parul Sehgal
title: Brit Bennett’s New Novel Explores the Power and Performance of Race
description: In “The Vanishing Half,” her follow-up to “The Mothers,” Brit Bennett writes about twin sisters from Louisiana who set out in very different directions.
content: No nation can lay lasting claim to a genre, save perhaps one. The story of racial passing is a uniquely and intensely American form. From its earliest avatars, the 19th-century novel “Clotel,” for example, to Langston Hughes’s short stories and Nella Larsen’s 1929 masterpiece, “Passing,” to the melodrama films of the 1950s, like “Pinky” and “Imitation of Life,” it is a story central to the American imagination, re-examined and retold so regularly it seems to enjoy a perpetual heyday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Kandell
title: Stanley Ho, Who Turned Macau Into a Global Gambling Hub, Dies at 98
description: Mr. Ho led the tiny Chinese territory’s transformation into the world’s most lucrative gambling destination.
content: Stanley Ho, the opportunistic casino tycoon who led the transformation of the tiny territory of Macau, off the coast of China, into the world’s most lucrative gambling destination, died on Tuesday in Hong Kong. He was 98.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Seibert
title: Lincoln Center Opens Its Vaults for Dance Week
description: Online highlights: Time-capsule treasures from “Live at Lincoln Center” and new works by Stephen Petronio and Mark Morris.
content: The shuttering of theaters has caused the dance world untold damage, yet there has been an upshot: the increased accessibility of high-end dance, as productions stream online, free. In a way, the moment harkens back to an earlier time, when the kind of dance you could see in the fancy theaters of Lincoln Center was regularly broadcast on public television. Or at least, that’s a historical connection suggested by Lincoln Center at Home’s upcoming week of online dance programming.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: Act Surprised! Obie Awards Go Virtual, Giving Winners Heads-Up
description: The ceremony, honoring Off and Off Off Broadway theater, has been forced online by the pandemic, and is being recorded and edited before the June 4 streaming.
content: The Obie Awards, the freewheeling ceremony honoring theater performed Off and Off Off Broadway, has come up with its pandemic plan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anita Shet
title: Will the Pandemic Lead to Outbreaks of Other Maladies?
description: Vaccinations worldwide have dropped as the fight against the coronavirus continues.
content: An unusual silence fills the waiting area of my fellow pediatrician’s office in suburban Maryland. On a typical day, one would expect to see the animated bustle of children. Nowadays, only two out of 10 scheduled visits might take place. Unused vaccine vials rapidly accumulate as families shelter at home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Gardner
title: I Am Asking New York Not to Forget Us
description: After 9/11, New York left paramedics behind. I fear the same will happen with the coronavirus.
content: On the morning of Sept. 11, 2001, I was working as a paramedic in Lower Manhattan. I responded to the attacks on the World Trade Center. In dust so thick it shrouded the sun, my fellow rescue workers and I picked our way through the rubble, looking for survivors. Very few of us had masks. When I got home and took a shower, the runoff clogged the drain and collected around my ankles like reconstituted cement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage
title: House to Vote on Limiting F.B.I. Power to Collect Americans’ Internet Data
description: Lawmakers compromised on an ambiguously worded amendment that narrows a failed but popular Senate proposal.
content: WASHINGTON — House leaders have agreed to permit a vote on tightening limits on when the F.B.I. may collect Americans’ internet browsing and search records during national security investigations, after negotiations over Memorial Day weekend between two California Democrats, Representatives Zoe Lofgren and Adam B. Schiff.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
title: Outcry Over Cummings Turns Public Against Johnson for 1st Time
description: The image of a powerful official flouting the lockdown rules has struck a nerve in a way that the government’s haphazard response to the virus has not.
content: LONDON — For more than two months, Prime Minister Boris Johnson has floundered in his response to the coronavirus — abandoning widespread testing, dragging his feet on imposing a lockdown, leaving nursing homes unprotected, and muddling his message about how to reopen the British economy.
source.name: The New York Times

title: No Corrections: May 26, 2020
description: No corrections appeared in print on Tuesday, May 26, 2020.
content: No corrections appeared in print on Tuesday, May 26, 2020.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rawiya Kameir
title: From the Philippines to Harvard, Boyhood to Womanhood, a Coming-of-Age Across Borders
description: In “Fairest,” Meredith Talusan looks back on her life lived at the intersection of genders, races, sexualities and cultures.
content: The journalist Meredith Talusan was a young teenager in a small town in the Philippines when, in 1989, the legal scholar Kimberlé Crenshaw proposed the concept of intersectionality to describe the ways in which race and gender and sexuality overlap to either amplify or ease discrimination. Decades later, as social media has catapulted academic jargon into everyday vocabulary, the term has become warped to signify a restructuring of society, with minorities at the top. But still this theory — that identity categories are not mutually exclusive, but integrated components of a single, multidimensional experience — remains immensely relevant today. Talusan’s debut memoir, “Fairest,” embodies both Crenshaw’s original framework as well as its contemporary misunderstanding, rendering an intellectual debate intimate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: Compiled by Jeremy Engle and John Otis
title: Weekly News Quiz for Students: China, Dam Breach, Michael Jordan's Sneaker
description: How well did you follow the news this past week? How many of these 10 questions can you get right?
content: How well did you follow the news this past week? How many of these 10 questions can you get right?
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Reopening, in 5 Charts
description: As states ease lockdown orders, Americans are eating out, booking flights and buying houses again. Here’s what that looks like.
content: Want this in your inbox each morning? Sign up here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amal El-Mohtar
title: Visit These Science-Fiction Worlds to Make Sense of Our Own
description: Racial strife, consent, wealth inequality: The issues swirling in these fantastical settings may seem familiar.
content: Plans, like time, have proved remarkably elastic during this pandemic, and books I’d intended to discuss here have been delayed half a season or more, while books I didn’t cover upon their release have taken on new significance. So consider this column a chaotic pantry from which to prepare a week’s worth of meals: Here are six very different books, remarkable enough in their difference, I hope, to feed at least that many different hungers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Lerner
title: The Backward Logic of Austerity Threatens America’s Most Vibrant Campus
description: CUNY must be saved from needless cuts.
content: Last month the administration at Brooklyn College, part of the City University of New York, announced that — in anticipation of a coming budget crisis — departments must reduce their course offerings by 25 percent. This will mean firing large numbers of adjunct professors, some of whom will lose their health insurance, in the middle of a pandemic. (Mass firings have already started at other CUNY campuses, 450 to date at John Jay alone; they could happen at Brooklyn any day.) Remaining classes will then swell, which is bad for in-person education, but worse if classes remain online, as anybody who has tried to teach on Zoom can attest. The administration has said the projected savings from terminating adjuncts and ballooning classes at Brooklyn College would be $1.4 million. On the scale of New York State’s budget, the system’s main funding source, that’s a rounding error; for our adjuncts and our students, it’s a disaster. After years of being brutalized by Albany, CUNY has apparently so thoroughly internalized the backward logic of austerity that it responds to crisis by attacking itself.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Long Island Is on the Verge of Reopening
description: A restart would leave New York City as the only region in the state to remain on “pause.”
content: The densely populated suburbs of Long Island are on the cusp of restarting parts of their economy, leaving the strong possibility that on Wednesday, New York City will be the only region in the state to remain on what Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo has labeled a “pause.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Lerner
title: The Backward Logic of Austerity Threatens America’s Most Vibrant Campus
description: CUNY must be saved from needless cuts.
content: Last month the administration at Brooklyn College, part of the City University of New York, announced that — in anticipation of a coming budget crisis — departments must reduce their course offerings by 25 percent. This will mean firing large numbers of adjunct professors, some of whom will lose their health insurance, in the middle of a pandemic. (Mass firings have already started at other CUNY campuses, 450 to date at John Jay alone; they could happen at Brooklyn any day.) Remaining classes will then swell, which is bad for in-person education, but worse if classes remain online, as anybody who has tried to teach on Zoom can attest. The administration has said the projected savings from terminating adjuncts and ballooning classes at Brooklyn College would be $1.4 million. On the scale of New York State’s budget, the system’s main funding source, that’s a rounding error; for our adjuncts and our students, it’s a disaster. After years of being brutalized by Albany, CUNY has apparently so thoroughly internalized the backward logic of austerity that it responds to crisis by attacking itself.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Tiny Love Stories: ‘It’s OK if You Meet Someone’
description: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
content: A very drunk man won’t stop telling me about trains. The Cape Town summer is hot, the night sticky, my drink warm. This gay bar will surely sink, given the number of heaving bodies shoved inside it. I nod at the train-talker, plotting an escape, and you appear. Your accent is cute, your beard cuter, and you tell the train guy that we’re here together. Suddenly, we are here together. It isn’t a lie; it’s a prophecy, and a good one at that. Ten years, three countries, five cities, four dogs and two toddlers later, we’re still here, together. — Michael McClelland
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: Union Insists Actors Shouldn’t Work Till Epidemic Is ‘Under Control’
description: Actors’ Equity Association, which represents 51,000 theater performers and stage managers, lays out guidelines aimed to keep its members safe.
content: Theater in America should not resume until there is fast, reliable testing for the novel coronavirus and widespread contact tracing, the labor union representing actors and stage managers said Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Donald G. McNeil Jr
title: A Virus-Hunter Falls Prey to a Virus He Underestimated
description: Peter Piot, 71, one of the giants of Ebola and AIDS research, is still battling a coronavirus infection that hit him “like a bus” in March.
content: “This is the revenge of the viruses,” said Dr. Peter Piot, the director of the London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine. “I’ve made their lives difficult. Now they’re trying to get me.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By William K. Rashbaum
title: A Car Salesman, a Macedonian Ex-Minister and a $45 Million Mask Scheme
description: Prosecutors charge a New Jersey man who was part of an unlikely crew that sought a lucrative deal to provide desperately needed protective equipment.
content: It is an unlikely cast of characters for a multimillion-dollar municipal procurement drama, even given the chaos generated by the deadly coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil MacFarquhar and Serge F. Kovaleski
title: A Pandemic Bright Spot: In Many Places, Less Crime
description: The absence of people outdoors has produced a rare positive payoff in most American cities, big and small.
content: Chief David Todd of the Fargo Police Department periodically abandons his desk to walk the beat downtown. In recent weeks, he found the North Dakota streets so utterly deserted that he commissioned a movie about it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nikole Hannah-Jones
title: For Families Already Stretched to the Limit, the Pandemic Is a Disaster
description: The Sydnor-Joneses had finally moved into an actual home by scrimping and saving. But the pandemic has stymied their resourcefulness.
content: The Sydnor-Joneses had finally moved into an actual home by scrimping and saving. But the pandemic has stymied their resourcefulness.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Dwyer
title: She Fed Her Sick Flock During the 1918 Pandemic. Her Legacy Lives On.
description: An old woman leaves a pot of food on a rock outside her daughter’s house. A century later, others roll trays of meals to people with Covid-19.
content: Listen hard.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liam Stack
title: The Pandemic Upends Islam’s Holiest Month
description: Zoom calls and socially distant food drives have replaced family gatherings and community prayers.
content: Ali Mamun, a Bangladeshi immigrant who worked as a psychiatrist in Brooklyn, contracted the coronavirus in March and died three weeks later, just days before the start of the Islamic holy month of Ramadan.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Long Island Is on the Verge of Reopening
description: A restart would leave New York City as the only region in the state to remain on “pause.”
content: The densely populated suburbs of Long Island are on the cusp of restarting parts of their economy, leaving the strong possibility that on Wednesday, New York City will be the only region in the state to remain on what Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo has labeled a “pause.”

title: The Pandemic Upends Islam’s Holiest Month

content: Ali Mamun, a Bangladeshi immigrant who worked as a psychiatrist in Brooklyn, contracted the coronavirus in March and died three weeks later, just days before the start of the Islamic holy month of Ramadan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Rasgon
title: Ex-Head of Australian Girls School Is Fit for Trial, Israeli Court Says
description: For six years, Australia has tried to extradite Malka Leifer to face charges of sexually assaulting her students but she claimed to be mentally ill.
content: TEL AVIV — An Israeli court ruled Tuesday that a former principal of a Jewish girls school in Australia accused of sexually assaulting her students has been faking mental illness for years and is fit to face extradition proceedings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason DeParle
title: Hunger Program’s Slow Start Leaves Millions of Children Waiting
description: Child hunger is soaring, but two months after Congress approved billions to replace school meals, only 15 percent of eligible children had received benefits.
content: WASHINGTON — As child hunger soars to levels without modern precedent, an emergency program Congress created two months ago has reached only a small fraction of the 30 million children it was intended to help.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Gose
title: Distressed Real Estate Market Beckons Opportunistic Buyers
description: Investment firms are sitting on “a staggering amount of dry powder” as they wait for big property discounts brought on by the pandemic.
content: Hoping to take advantage of wreckage in the wake of the coronavirus pandemic, investors are preparing to snap up commercial real estate at rock-bottom prices.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Gordon
title: Run the Jewels Is Rewriting Rap’s Rules
description: El-P and Killer Mike teamed up in their 30s after careers on hip-hop’s commercial periphery. Now their lighthearted side project is their high-stakes life’s work.
content: “Move ya ass” music. Richard Petty and Dale Earnhardt music. Or, and this is quite specific: “The most frigid of New York days, and you’re walking out of Katz’s with a pastrami sandwich, and somebody punches you in your face” music.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Warner Music Launches Its I.P.O.
description: The recording company, which has musicians like Ed Sheeran on its books, tries to cash in on the streaming boom with a listing that would value it at up to $13.3 billion.
content: The Warner Music Group, the home of stars like Ed Sheeran, Cardi B and Led Zeppelin, announced on Tuesday that it would proceed with an initial public offering that would value the company at up to $13.3 billion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Conger and Davey Alba
title: Twitter Refutes Inaccuracies in Trump’s Tweets for First Time
description: Twitter added a link to two of President Trump’s tweets in which he had made false claims about mail-in ballots, urging people to “get the facts.”
content: OAKLAND, Calif. — Twitter added information to refute the inaccuracies in President Trump’s tweets for the first time on Tuesday, after years of pressure over its inaction on his false and threatening posts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Biryanis With Something Extra
description: The Biryani Bol from Rahi and Adda Indian Canteen come with a bread-sealed clay pot for diners to keep.
content: Until Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo decides that it’s safe enough for New York City’s restaurants to start indoor table service, many have pivoted to offer food for take out and sometimes delivery. And at Rahi in the West Village and Adda Indian Canteen in Long Island City, Queens, a bonus comes with the Lucknow biryani to go, a covered clay pot that you heat the dish in, and then get to keep. The pot is sealed with bread dough. Bake it for 30 to 40 minutes, slice through the dough to lift the lid, then dig into the steaming mixtures to find layers of chiles, onions and forceful spices mingling with extra long grain basmati rice and a featured ingredient, like chicken, succulent goat on the bone, chunks of rich lamb or assorted vegetables like cauliflower with paneer. Each pot, from the chefs Chintan Pandya and Soham Deshpande, serves about two people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: Inside the Dizzying Effort to Pitch Trump to Black Voters
description: Joe Biden’s “you ain’t black” gaffe was immediate grist for an online show called “Black Voices for Trump.” But its cast of Trump advisers routinely ignores the president’s history of divisive remarks.
content: WASHINGTON — Nearly every week this spring, President Trump’s re-election team has held one of the most peculiar events of the 2020 online campaign: “Black Voices for Trump Real Talk.” It’s a dizzying effort by Mr. Trump’s black advisers to put their spin on his record — often with a hall-of-mirrors quality, as they push false claims about opponents while boosting a president who retweets racist material.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: In Audacious Move, Georgia and Florida Governors Offer to Host G.O.P. Convention
description: The party is still contractually obligated to hold the event in North Carolina, but President Trump has threatened a change of location as the state’s Democratic governor urges caution because of the coronavirus.
content: The governors of Georgia and Florida, seizing on a tweet from President Trump, made an audacious move on Tuesday, offering their states’ hosting services for the Republican National Convention, which the party is contractually obligated to hold in Charlotte, N.C.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Maslin Nir
title: White Woman Is Fired After Calling Police on Black Man in Central Park
description: Video of the incident touched off intense discussions about the history of black people being falsely reported to the police.
content: The incident appears to have begun as one of those banal and brusque dust-ups between two New Yorkers. A black man, an avid birder, asked a white woman to leash her dog in Central Park, as the rules required. She refused.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pete Wells
title: That Dish, That Restaurant: Vivid Memories to Savor
description: Our critic hasn’t eaten out in more than two months. But recipes can let us recapture certain tastes and moments, and remember how a restaurant meal can enchant.
content: Gourmet used to run a recipe-request column called You Asked For It. It was everybody’s favorite part of the magazine. Everybody, that is, except Gourmet’s test-kitchen cooks, who drove themselves crazy getting the recipes into a form that people at home could follow.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Weiner
title: The Quarantine Bubbles Are Coming and I, for One, Am Stressed
description: How do you decide who belongs in yours? What if you join and find it’s not working out? And what if you aren’t invited to one at all?
content: Truly, the coronavirus is a gift that keeps on giving.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kara Swisher
title: Twitter Must Cleanse the Trump Stain
description: The president is spreading a vile conspiracy theory on the platform. Maybe Twitter should finally hold him to its rules.
content: “Please delete those tweets,” the widower begged in a letter last week to Twitter’s chief executive, Jack Dorsey. “My wife deserves better.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Warzel
title: You Are Not Working From Home
description: How to make sure the rise in remote work doesn’t mean the death of work-life balance.
content: If you are one of the privileged 40 percent of workers who can do their jobs remotely, you’ve spent the last few months working from home. Maybe you’re struggling. Or maybe you’ve achieved Diamond Medallion WFH status — which includes but is not limited to sending an email from the toilet using the phrase “let’s circle back.” Whether it’s going well or miserably, you are doing your job from where you live.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 2 Weeks, 6.5 Million Coronavirus Tests as Wuhan Nears Goal
description: The Chinese city where the outbreak began is seeking to test all its 11 million residents, and the pandemic has forced the fashion industry to take a hard look in the mirror.
content: 新冠病毒疫情最新消息
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sydney Ember
title: Biden, Urging Face Masks, Calls Trump a ‘Fool’ for Not Wearing One
description: Joseph Biden, in his first in-person interview since the coronavirus curtailed his campaign, suggested the president was being “falsely masculine’’ by refusing to wear a mask.
content: Joseph R. Biden Jr. laced into President Trump on Tuesday, calling him an “absolute fool” for refusing to wear a mask in public on Memorial Day and for appearing to scoff at the former vice president for wearing one.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joan Silber
title: In His New Book, a War Novelist Turns to More Intimate Battles
description: “Red Dress in Black and White,” by Elliot Ackerman, features an American woman anxious to leave her Turkish husband as political unrest rages in Istanbul.
content: RED DRESS IN BLACK AND WHITEBy Elliot Ackerman
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Campaigning Amid Crisis: Lessons From 2008
description: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, May 26, 2020.
content: “We could have had a shooting war in the Gulf in the middle of the financial crisis and nobody would have cared.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: Athing Mu Might Be America’s Fastest Teenager. How Much Faster Will She Be in 2021?
description: Mu was heading for the Olympic Trials with a shot to make the United States team when the Tokyo Games were postponed. A year from now, she and other budding stars should be that much better.
content: Athing Mu’s days are a lot less complicated than they were supposed to be.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Carey
title: Risky Strategy by Many Private Colleges Leaves Them Exposed
description: Chasing after a shrinking pool of wealthy students by increasing spending, and now vulnerable to closure because of the pandemic.
content: Will my college go bankrupt?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shannon Doyne
title: Should Students Be Required to Take the SAT and ACT to Apply to College?
description: The University of California has announced that SAT and ACT scores no longer factor in its admissions decisions. Should other colleges and universities follow suit?
content: Do you think standardized tests like the SAT and ACT correctly measure students’ academic knowledge and skills? Do they serve as accurate indicators of how well students will do with college-level course work? Do the scores serve as an objective, standard measure for colleges looking to compare students from around the country who are vying for acceptance, while taking into account the differences between their high school education, their families’ backgrounds and the communities from where they’re from?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By T. J. Stiles
title: Guns, Gunfights and the Legends of the Wild West
description: Jim Rasenberger’s “Revolver” explores Sam Colt and the invention of the six-shooter, while Tom Clavin’s “Tombstone” looks at the gunfight at the O.K. Corral.
content: REVOLVERSam Colt and the Six-Shooter That Changed AmericaBy Jim Rasenberger
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Taylor Lorenz
title: Step Chickens and the Rise of TikTok ‘Cults’
description: Fandoms are forming around a new kind of influencer: the charismatic cult leader.
content: Last week, a new name broke into Apple’s most-downloaded social networking apps. Among the usual suspects of Instagram, Facebook and TikTok appeared an app called Stepchickens, with a cryptic blue selfie as its logo.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Griffith
title: When the C.E.O., Already Facing a Crisis, Gets the Coronavirus
description: Business cratered at Booking Holdings, the online travel giant. Then its chief executive found out he was sick, too.
content: Glenn Fogel was in crisis mode.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noam Scheiber
title: Uber and Lyft Drivers Sue for New York Unemployment Benefits
description: In the latest challenge over their labor status, gig workers say the state is illegally failing to pay them jobless benefits in a timely way.
content: Doh Ouattara drove for Uber and Lyft from 2016 until mid-March of this year, when he became concerned about the pandemic. With three children under 6 to provide for, he decided to apply for unemployment benefits.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Corinna da Fonseca-Wollheim
title: A Pulse-Slowing Playlist for an Unmoored Time
description: Here are seven works that speak to the coronavirus time warp, in which days creep along but months vanish in a flash.
content: Before the coronavirus, investigating how humans perceive time was mostly the work of psychologists. Then the pandemic confined half the globe to their homes, upending routines and blurring the markers we’d relied on to keep track.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sophia June
title: Recent Commercial Real Estate Transactions
description: Recent commercial real estate transactions in New York.
content: $4.6 MILLION
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: New Site Aggregates Food News
description: The cookbook author David Joachim writes the weekly DigestThis.news, from the barbecue website Amazing Ribs.
content: A free weekly online compendium of food news, DigestThis.news, started publishing last week. It’s an offshoot of Amazing Ribs, a website that’s about all things barbecue. David Joachim, a cookbook author who also writes for Amazing Ribs, is at the helm. The site covers topics like restaurants, health, regulations, science, cooking, new books and more — mostly culled from other sources. Look for everything from the use of murder hornets in spirits to Food & Wine magazine’s best new chefs selection for this year.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Joe Biden’s Gaffe, and Advice for His Campaign
description: Readers discuss a comment Mr. Biden made about his support from blacks and call on him to be more in the public eye.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas L. Friedman
title: Mike Pompeo Is the Worst Secretary of State Ever
description: Where’s the Republican uproar over what’s gone on under his watch?
content: If you thought the volume on the Trump-Twitter-Fox noise distraction machine was turned up extra loud in the past few weeks, it was not only to deflect attention from the nearly 100,000 Americans who’ve died from Covid-19, but also from the confirmation that on President Trump’s watch our country suffered the first deadly terrorist attack on U.S. soil since 9/11 that was planned abroad.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: Republicans Tried to Suppress the Vote in Florida. And Failed.
description: Voters overwhelmingly wanted to restore former felons’ voting rights.
content: Who gets to cast a ballot in Florida, the nation’s largest swing state, could well determine who will be the next leader of the country, and in the middle of the biggest global crisis in generations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ernest Owens
title: I Have Not Missed the Amy Coopers of the World
description: The video of a white woman threatening a black man in Central Park illustrates exactly why I’m so relieved to be spending more time inside.
content: During a recent session conducted over Zoom, my therapist told me I was “glowing.” In the middle of a pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert C. Yeager
title: Classic Car Auctions Upended by Coronavirus
description: Splashy events that drew big, lucrative crowds have been canceled, and a market that is already growing more comfortable with online sales may find them more attractive in the future.
content: After collapsing last year, auctions for collector vehicles started 2020 on a roll, ringing up more than $300 million in sales at events in January in Scottsdale, Ariz., and in March on Amelia Island in Florida.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin and Hiroko Masuike
title: Reopening, Child Hunger, J.K. Rowling: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kwame Anthony Appiah
title: Should a Parent of Two Children Split Inheritance Equally?
description: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on dividing your estate equally among heirs, taking advantage of the CARES Act and using PayPal to pay contractors.
content: This is the situation: An elderly parent has a fair amount of money and two children. One is wealthy with luxury properties, a spouse and no children. This child lives far away and visits only sporadically. The other lives near the parent, earns a modest salary, has children and several grandchildren and regularly visits and helps the elderly parent. This parent thinks it’s only fair to leave her children an equal share of her assets. Is this, in fact, ethical? Name Withheld
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyson Krueger
title: How to Raise a Happy, Carefree Butterfly
description: Online sales of caterpillar kits are booming, and the chance to watch an insect turn into a butterfly has caught the imaginations of every age group in the age of social distancing.
content: Josh Gipper, who lives in Denver, was considering getting his family a pet. He thought it would be fun for his 3-year-old daughter and 6-year-old-son to watch a creature grow, and he hoped it would also bring meaning and love to their lives.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Hanc
title: Keeping Clients Fit During the Pandemic by Going Virtual
description: What to do with a business that involves close physical contact with clients? Innovate and, if you’re lucky, grow — but at a distance.
content: This article is part of Owning the Future, a series on how small businesses across the country are coping with the coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Living Together in a Pandemic: How Are Your Relationships Faring?
description: We want to hear your stories. Submissions needn’t be limited to romantic partners.
content: It doesn’t take an expert to tell you that relationships can flourish — or wither — in times of stress. Add months on end without the ability to significantly mingle with others, along with the physical and emotional toll that comes with a pandemic, and this period we’re living through may just be the ultimate relationship test.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court Refuses to Stop Order to Move Inmates From Virus-Ravaged Prison
description: The court’s action left in place a court order requiring prison officials to move more than 800 older or medically vulnerable prisoners from a facility that has seen nine deaths from Covid-19.
content: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Tuesday refused a request from the Trump administration to block a trial judge’s ruling that had ordered federal prison officials to take steps to protect more than 800 older or medically vulnerable inmates at Elkton Federal Correctional Institution in Ohio, where nine prisoners have died from the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos and Michael S. Schmidt
title: Republicans Sue Pelosi to Block House Proxy Voting During Pandemic
description: The suit filed by Representative Kevin McCarthy, the minority leader, opens a new front in Republicans’ push to throw suspicion on Democratic efforts to make it easier to vote amid the outbreak.
content: Republican leaders sued Speaker Nancy Pelosi and top congressional officials on Tuesday to block the House of Representatives from using a proxy voting system set up by Democrats to allow for remote legislating during the coronavirus pandemic, calling it unconstitutional.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Creswell
title: A Socially Distanced Las Vegas? What Are the Odds?
description: Will a stripped-down version of the city attract the same number of visitors who used to come to party at pools, dance in nightclubs and gamble in casinos?
content: For decades, the El Cortez Hotel & Casino in downtown Las Vegas has been known for single-deck blackjack.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Stevenson and Keith Bradsher
title: China’s Young Struggle for Jobs in the Post-Outbreak Era
description: Finding work for a generation has become a major priority for the country’s leaders, who have promised a better life in exchange for a lack of political freedom.
content: Before China can fully recover from the devastation of the coronavirus outbreak, it needs to find people like Huang Bing a job.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Schmitt, Charlie Savage and Noah Weiland
title: Longtime Pentagon Watchdog Stepping Down From Post
description: President Trump had ousted the official last month from a new role overseeing the administration’s spending of pandemic relief money.
content: WASHINGTON — Glenn A. Fine, ousted by President Trump last month as head of a watchdog panel assigned to oversee how his administration spends trillions of taxpayer dollars in coronavirus pandemic relief, announced Monday he was resigning from his Pentagon job.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Drape
title: Charlatan, a Belmont Stakes Contender, Tests Positive for a Banned Substance
description: Charlatan was one of two horses trained by Bob Baffert that tested positive for a banned numbing agent at a recent meet in Arkansas.
content: Two horses trained by the Hall of Famer Bob Baffert tested positive for a banned substance at a recently concluded meet at Oaklawn Park in Arkansas, according to a person familiar with the testing process. One of the horses, Charlatan, won a division of the Arkansas Derby on May 2 and was considered a top contender to win the Belmont Stakes on June 20.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Cocktails Beyond the Margarita, Mojito and Pisco Sour
description: “Spirits of Latin America” by Ivy Mix uses the classics as a starting point.
content: Ivy Mix, an owner of Leyenda, a bar in Brooklyn, has put the focus on tequila, rum and pisco in her useful new book, “Spirits of Latin America.” Agave, sugar cane and grapes: Each one has its own chapter, giving the history, production methods and cultural influences of tequila (and mezcal), rum (and cachaça) and pisco (and Bolivian singani), and dipping into matters of archaeology, colonialism, slavery and politics. Cocktail recipes are included for all the liquors. Ms. Mix points out that all tequilas are mezcals, but not all mezcals are tequilas, and why; that there are easily defined types of rum; and that Prohibition killed a thriving American market for pisco, which is just now coming back. The cocktail recipes feature classics, as well as Ms. Mix’s recipes, like the lovely Palo Negro, combining tequila, rum and sherry. Her Brooklyn Burro with rum, lime, ginger syrup and pineapple juice is a winner.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Bitecofer
title: Why a Biden Victory Hinges on Picking the Right Running Mate
description: The Democratic nominee needs someone to energize the party's coalition and balance the ticket.
content: Do vice-presidential picks matter? Conventional wisdom argues they have limited electoral impact.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ernest Owens
title: I Have Not Missed the Amy Coopers of the World
description: The video of a white woman threatening a black man in Central Park illustrates exactly why I’m so relieved to be spending more time inside.
content: During a recent session conducted over Zoom, my therapist told me I was “glowing.” In the middle of a pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker and Maggie Astor
title: Trump Pushes a Conspiracy Theory That Falsely Accuses a TV Host of Murder
description: On Twitter and at a news conference, the president said Joe Scarborough was responsible for the death of Lori Klausutis, who worked for him when he was a congressman. But Twitter refused her husband’s request to have the false tweets removed.
content: WASHINGTON — President Trump smeared a prominent television host on Tuesday from the lectern in the Rose Garden with an unfounded allegation of murder, taking the politics of rage and conspiracy theory to a new level even as much of the political world barely took notice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Somini Sengupta
title: Britain, Host of U.N. Climate Talks, Proposes Full-Year Pandemic Delay
description: The postponement, expected to be approved, could result in national recovery plans with high environmental costs, some diplomats say.
content: International negotiations designed to address the sweeping global threat of climate change will quite likely be delayed by a full year because of the coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Benner and Nicholas Fandos
title: Justice Dept. Ends Inquiries Into 3 Senators’ Stock Trades
description: Law enforcement officials told three senators that they would not be pursuing charges, but an investigation into trades by Senator Richard Burr of North Carolina appears to be proceeding.
content: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department notified three senators on Tuesday that it will not pursue insider trading charges against them after an investigation into stock transactions from the early days of the coronavirus pandemic did not find sufficient evidence they had broken the law, according to a person briefed on the investigations and congressional aides.
source.name: The New York Times
